That year she also made her first film appearance as the female lead in the comedy Postlagernd Turteltaube/ Poste restante turtledove (1952, Gerhard T. Buchholz). Next she played a Russian soldier in Die Spur führt nach Berlin/International Counterfeiters (1952, Frantisek Cáp). For this role she was awarded with the Bundesfilmpreis for Best Newcomer. In the following decade he played leading roles in such films as the war drama Die letzte Brücke/The Last Bridge (1954, Helmut Käutner) with Maria Schell, the biographical drama Canaris (1954, Alfred Weidenmann) opposite O.E. Hasse as the chief of the intelligence service of Nazi Germany, the Heimatfilm Die Geierwally (1954, Frantisek Cáp) with Carl Möhner, and the crime film Herz ohne Gnade/Heart Without Pity (1958, Viktor Tourjansky) with Hansjörg Felmy. She also appeared in foreign films, such as A Time to Love and a Time to Die (1958, Douglas Sirk) based on the novel by Erich Maria Remarque and starring John Gavin. Barbara Rütting played the female lead opposite Kirk Douglas in Town Without Pity (1961, Gottfried Reinhardt), a hard hitting, depressing and brutal courtroom drama about the rape of a 16-year old girl (Christine Kaufmann). At IMDb, Michael Elliott writes that there was a lot of controversy around the film at the time: “United Artists put a warning on the film and asked theater owners not to let anyone under 17 into the film. Several theater owners wouldn't even show the film due to its subject matter. I think all of this controversy hurt the film when it was released but I think it's about time film buffs and film historians go back and take a look at this film and include it with the greatest courtroom films out there. This film still manages to shock and be outrageous nearly forty-five years after being released.” Rütting appeared with Martin Held in the romantic comedy Liebe will gelernt sein/Love wants to be learned (1963, Kurt Hoffmann), based on a play by Erich Kästner, and in such Edgar Wallace krimis as Der Zinker/The Squeaker (1963, Alfred Vohrer) with Heinz Drache, and Das Phantom von Soho/Murder by Proxy (1964, Franz Josef Gottlieb) with Dieter Borsche. She had a supporting part in the war drama Operation Crossbow (1965, Michael Anderson) starring Sophia Loren. When the German cinema got in a deep crisis, Rütting appeared more and more on TV. She guest starred in such popular krimi series as Der Kommissar/The Commissioner (1975), Der Alte/The Old Fox (1980) and Derrick (1981). In the meanwhile she also was active as an author and wrote since her debut novel Die maßlose Zärtlichkeit (1970, The immoderate tenderness) several successful children's and (vegetarian) cook books. In 1983 she retired from acting and since then she became a well known human rights and animal welfare activist. She organized help projects and taught cooking in hospitals for victims of the Chernobyl disaster. In 2003, she was elected into the Landtag (state parliament) of Bavaria for the Green Party. In 2008 she left the Landtag and the Green party. Barbara Rütting was married to Hans Rütting (1946 - 1951) and to count Heinrich von Einsiedel (1955 - 1964). Both marriages ended in a divorce. Between 1969 and 1988 her partner was Lutz Hochstraate. Sources: BarbaraRuetting.de, Wikipedia (German and English), and IMDb.
